column4: I accidently took my name off of the suddoers list and cant do any sudo commands. Any idea how to get back on it?
If you can't ssh in as root or another account that has sudo ability, you're pretty much toast...
Advice:  Always have a back door of some sort.
Yeah that is what I was figuring. So once I boot in recovery I use visudo to edit the suddoers file correct?
Yep.  Use the "visudo" command.  It'll pick the right file and handle any concurrency issues (not that you'll have any in recovery mode, however).
What were you trying to do with these changes you've made?
Lam_: I figured it out... the admin group looks like this: admin:x:114:  and I need to make it look like this admin:x:114:gbrent
I was trying to make me apart of the root group also or something. It was a week ago and I just left it alone for a while
is this action also going to require the recovery console?
can I just boot off a live cd and change it?

You weren't far off, if you were running a distro like Fedora.  But for a sudo-based distro that typically doesn't assign a password directly to root, however, the key is the admin group in /etc/sudoers, as you now know.
Yep.  Just mount the / filesystem (if the live distro doesn't do that for you) and fix it.
Either a Ubuntu Live CD or Knoppix or any other live and/or recovery distro should work.
cool thanks man. Im doing that over lunch when i get home.
